oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: The history of Country Music - Volume 2 - Recording 2 - Side 2
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Country music history program with voice overs and commercial recordings likely for radio broadcast. Internet sources say the producer and narrator is Lee Cash. Subject matter pertains to the history of country music and recording is likely a syndicated radio show. Tape is labeled as: volume two, recording two, side two.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: (00:00) The History of Country Music (Unconfirmed) ([Unidentified]) -- (00:04) An unidentified speaker discusses the political landscape of 1963 -- (00:35) Talk Back Trembling Lips (Ernest Ashworth) -- (03:06) An unidentified speaker lists Sonny James' accomplishments, and Sonny James reflects on his appreciation for his career -- (03:41) The Minute You're Gone (Sonny James) -- (06:05) Faron Young recalls meeting Roger Miller in Nashville, Tennessee -- (06:41) King of the Road (Roger Miller) -- (08:52) An unidentified speaker and Red Sovine discuss how Sovine did not believe "Getty Up Go" would be a hit record -- (10:14) Getty Up Go (Red Sovine) -- (14:00) An unidentified speaker discusses how Johnny Cash praised Tom T. Hall's "The Ballad of Forty Dollars" -- (14:14) Hall reflects on people's desire to have a motto in death -- (14:53) The ballad of Forty Dollars (Tom T. Hall) -- (17:41) An unidentified speaker reflects on "One Has My Name (The Other Has My Heart)" -- (18:13) One Has My Name (The Other Has My Heart) (Jerry Lee Lewis) -- (20:52) An unidentified speaker reflects on Cash's professional career -- (21:24) Folsom Prison Blues (Johnny Cash) -- (24:01) An unidentified speaker reflects on the influence of Jimmie Rodgers, Hank Williams, and Johnny Cash -- (24:57) Mother Maybelle Carter praises Cash, and Cash jokes about "Walk the Line" -- (25:47) Walk the Line (Johnny Cash) -- (28:00) The History of Country Music (Unconfirmed) ([Unidentified])
